review_title: An once very good company that have drastically changed with the current focus on bringing key jobs back to Finland.
pros:
Great benefits package (not including salary) and equal opportunity employer (until the last reorg).
Sadly, the whole company culture have changed and it is no longer the equal opportunity employer Nokia used to be for years.
cons: After the last global reorg, the focus is entirely on giving key jobs only to Finnish people in Finland and remaining less important jobs to people in India and China. Most other people were fired regardless of their past performance !

pros: Work culture in most locations tends to be less than demanding. It is still a very global company, compared to competitors where the top layer must be from a certain country. It has survived several downturns. With the merger with ALu, it will emerge as a large player in an industry with guaranteed demand for the next 5 years.
cons: Management has made so many U-turns in core strategy that it is a case study in not knowing what to do and still surviving. A big change that has crept in over the years is that internal maneuvering has become more important than great work at the customer interface. HR is known to be the department least interested in the human angle. Quality of people has eroded over the years.

pros: Excellent people, good work-life balance, good tools/processes, treats contractors/partners fairly, good work environment, truly global company - opportunities to work with cultures across the globe,colleagues becomes friends, Socially responsible employer - bridge program for departing employees eg. training, retrenchment packages, seed money for those who wished to start business.
cons: Cons only of late due to company fallen behind in the smartphone stakes.  Reorgs over the past 2 year makes it difficult to work under cloud of uncertainty and can be very frustrating at times.  Used to have great IT services, support structure/framework but not anymore after recent decision to outsource bulk of IT services.

pros: Great work culture, many opportunities and for most part, especially when offered overseas roles, the pay is lucrative and very family friendly.
cons: Too many organisational changes with massive cuts towards the end, oft-times resulting in the ones staying shouldering the tasks of 2 or more.  The cuts should also be deeper at the senior and mid-senior leadership levels, where savings (if that was the intent) will be more significant, rather than from the bottom half, where all the last mile work is being executed.

review_title: Best place to work in the past
pros:
The comments below are more indicative of "Old Nokia".  "New Nokia" nowadays is a different company and may not have these Pros:
1. Great culture. Respect for individual. 
2. Great personal development opportunities
3. Great benefits and work life balance, flexi-hours.
cons:
1. Pay is average or low (depending on who you work for).  The pay difference can be a big gap sometimes even for people who worked for years there.
2. Company is now going through major reorganization to downsize to a smaller, more efficient company to survive. This is a good thing for the company, but definitely not a great thing for individuals as benefits get taken away, people get outsourced, or have to do multiple person's job.  Huge uncertainty with the company's future.

review_title: Cozy place to stay if that suits you
pros: - amazing place to have kids/enjoy work-life balance if you can put up with the bs, - friendly colleagues, good culture, - good software practices cultivated, - some of the tasks I carried out there were very interesting and I learnt a lot from them;
cons: - the Process is God in this company, - expect to spend most of the time writing tests in a proprietary language, - my manager had almost thirty people under him, expect little to no contact, 1in90 meetings happened once a year and my impression is they happened to check this item off some checklist, (though accounting for so many people under him, my manager did really well, very relaxed, no micromanaging), - expect checking off upper management checklists and caring about pointless statistics, - I found a lot of my work too repetitive, - Huge (capital 'H') amount of domain knowledge necessary. Non-transferable, unless you want to jump to competition, - At the end of my time there the CI infrastructure was not performant/malfunctioning to the point of seriously slowing down development (and just being a pain overall) - Company motto used to be "Connecting People", but the message from the upper management was constantly: "Regaining/Maintaining the leadership in our domain!" It does feel like the vision died and now it's about money and being better than competition which is just sad.

pros: - Helpful, nice, dedicated employees. - Awesome managers (for the most part) - Great benefits system (500k HUF cafeteria, car benefit or cash compensation above job grade 10,etc.). - Good yearly bonus system. - Employees are looked after, great attention to mental health, personal support services. - Multiple opportunities within the company. - Varied home office contracts, and you get payed extra if you work from home. - Great Finnish mentality across the globe, - Truly diverse and multicultural company.
cons: - Poor employee retention capabilities for managers (e.g.: one time increase limit is 10% in Hungary), - Salaries are not matching job market, competitors give higher salary. - You initially have to negotiate a good salary for yourself, otherwise you'll be stuck with it, and you'll only get yearly inflation compensation. - You have to switch to a higher job grade position to (somewhat meaningfully) increase your base salary. Car benefit cash compensation at JG10 or above can help to increase income (if you don't need the car).

job_title: Electrical Engineer in New York, NY
pros: Cutting edge technology. Work with seasoned experts in the field. Pension is great. Company wants you to make your career here and stay for a long time. Long time employees have a great work ethic and deep knowledge of the products as well as the nitty gritty details. Pay is good. Steady job, great job security (despite occasional global layoffs). Overall, quality of the hardware engineers here is great; excellent attention to detail. People are very nice and kind, in a genuine way. It is nice to work with genuine good hearted people, and you will find many here. You are building products which are the backbone of the Internet communications infrastructure. Management is highly technically adept, there is little "fat" in the organization as far as I could tell.
cons: Not much collaboration between team members, much of the work is individually focused. While many people indeed contribute to the creation of each product, the team dynamic is non-existent because of the manner in which the work is doled out individually. Little investment into cultivating employees, lack of programs to adequately train newer employees. Average age of employees is quite high, which results in a subpar culture for young engineers. Little recognition for work performed (perhaps the managers are overburdened with so much work that they cannot spare the time to celebrate any achievements. But this results in degraded performance in the long term, as there are few incentives to perform other than money. They should realize that employees will do their best work when achievements are recognized). Morale seems low, unfortunately.

review_title: Long timers are valued way lesser. Management is helpless/don't care.
pros:
WLB is usually good.
Leadership is taking some measures in terms of people policies that cater to needs outside of salaries. 
3months of paternity leave for eg. is pretty good. 
Leave policies are employee friendly.
cons:
Senior management lack the leadership qualities and seldom support the subordinates.
No motivation from within the team, manager, which makes you complacent if you dont like fast paced environment.
If you are talented, likely you'd be under utilized here. 
No proper process for new joiners.
Lately the recruitment process is lackluster and management is desperate to get in people due to extremely high attrition
A good bunch of talented people already left/leaving.
Salary levels are not at par with market. 
Long term employees are not valued at all, yet managers boast of long term commitment. 
No efforts for retention, but ok to take people with lower experience at nearly 50% higher pay. 
Quality of work and WLB is going down since new joiners are scrambling with no proper skills to understand the large codebase, as a result of desperate hiring.
Bad outlook even with such promising 5G market potential.

pros:
It has a great culture of respect and speaking up. It also encourages learners to ask dumb questions without being ridiculed.

Off late, the business performance has also picked up, thanks to painful strategy resets and lots of actions to demolish information silos.

Chances of being fired or punished is very low as long as one can manage to avoid upsetting the folks above, beyond or at same level. Additionally, if you are a person who can propagate the culture while also getting some business results, you are likely to get promoted faster.
cons:
Pay, and chances to work on exciting products or artifacts are low.
A large chunk of people are working on menial stuff, and feedback from employees on topics beyond immediate managers' control take ages to make progress.

Of course, if the top guys are directly opening campaigns to find ideas, that is a great new way to get attention to your problems. But that is limited in scope.

Also, the company seems more relaxed, and on a holiday at an average, while of course many individual teams sweat it out to win business deals.

review_title: Great learning opportunities but fixed mindset in the processes and management, low-key career outlook
pros: Nokia has a great approach to encourage you to learn and grow knowledge-wise. They put effort into your development plan and you can access plenty of learning platforms also exams to get certified too. I think the company culture is great in general. The commitment to diversity and inclusion is outstanding. The Hungarian site provides an on-site general practitioner doctor, office GYM, and game room. Families can gain extra benefits and you can get safety insurance as well.
cons:
TL, DR: Old fashioned company, fixed mindset, job offers and salaries under the market trends, you have to wear multiple roles simultaneously to might get considered for promotion, hard to get promoted. 

- Nokia's job offers and salary options are way under the market trends, which is one of the main reasons why the company is facing enormous fluctuation and being understaffed. During my three years at Nokia, I got one time raise under 5% due to my contract's mandatory raise agreement. The purpose of these raise initiatives should be to keep employees competitive, but to be honest, compared to the inflation back in 2021 it was nothing technically. 

- Moving forward and getting promoted is almost impossible. I had to take multiple extra roles and work a lot to "maybe get considered" for promotion. At some point, it felt like I have to pray to get promoted to a higher job grade. Nokia is not capable to give you a promotion or salary raise at any time in a fiscal year, so you have to wait for a specific period. But don't expect too much anyway... Nokia has country-specific limits for salary raises so your dream raise percentage is going to remain only a dream. They are hiring a lot of fresh graduates and interns to save on employment costs. So if you are thinking about joining Nokia as a senior or medior employee you should expect that you will be mentoring a lot of people. Nokia is proud of being agile and does not hesitate to promote it, but in reality, it is not true.

- The entire company is a pure waterfall or uses a waterfall-agile hybrid approach for project management. If you are thinking about joining Nokia, I highly recommend landing a job in one of Nokia's R&D departments instead of the internal IT department, since you might land an offer with a higher salary range than in the IT dept.

pros: My comments are based on US employment - benefits and employment security and opportunities depend on the Country you work in. Steady Paycheck. Cash Pension Account. Generous Paid Vacation. Good Health Benefits
cons:
Pay in US has not kept up with similar companies. Constant layoffs - Every 3rd Thursday of the month. Layoff are semi-secretive - you only find out people have been let go when they disappear. In the 2010s there were multiple years without raises and most years the bonuses were reduced due to company not achieving goals.
Constant pressure to outsource to cheaper cost centers. People are secretive about their work so they cannot be easily replaced and team work is limited due to fear of being laid off. No 401K match but now there is Cash pension account. Not many US Holidays but generous paid vacation. Top heavy company even as direct reports have been continually reduced. Constant campus consolidations and pressure to eliminate US campuses. Not a safe environment to challenge the norm despite the company advertising a safe environment to speak up and challenge the norm. Career opportunities in the US are severely limited.

review_title: Good for getting started but don't stay too long
pros:
+ good colleagues, really helpful and nurturing towards beginners
+ flexible working hours
+ wfh
+ good work-life balance if you know to manage it/ impose it (not overpromissing, making sure you only put in the required 40hrs)
+ good bonuses and benefits
cons:
- salary isn't competitive
- raises don't even keep up with inflation
- minuscule (~4%) raises even for top performers
- once hired, don't expect your salary to keep up with the market or even with your newly-hired colleagues. it got to the point where the best engineer in the team was making WAY less than the newly-hired engineers
- no attempts at rewarding and retaining valuable employees
- hiring 3 students to make up for the engineer who left because he wouldn't get a decent raise
- manager isn't technical and only has high-level knowledge of the project yet he's the one giving bonuses and raises
- lot of bureaucracy
- the career oportunities are given to the people who've been at nokia for decades. skill doesn't seem to be a factor
- some managers impose working at the office
- after about 1yr, students are treated about the same as engineers. same responsabilities but drastically different benefits (engineers have performance bonuses, raises and make at least double what the students make)
- students don't qualify for company-wide bonuses
- being proactive and hardworking rarely gets you more than a pat on the back and a gift voucher

review_title: Disorganized, poorly managed in business department.
pros:
The company and workplace is very diverse and I met a lot of great employees and people. That was the most amazing part of the job. The location was in a renovated, walkable community with a small lake.

I transferred to the IOT lab and my team was amazing. Very hard-working and knowledgable. The quality of your work and time all depends what department you are in!
cons:
The business is very poorly managed. Upper management always wanted to present that they had everything together and the company was doing well financially, but they were not productive at all. There were meetings to schedule other meetings to schedule other meetings. Data management was also extremely disorganized, most likely due to all the acquisitions and discommunication between departments. All these factors caused projects to be delayed or incomplete. 

Most of the employees are very nice, but watch out for some of the older creepy men if you are a younger woman. I experienced way too many inappropriate, sexist comments and sexual verbal advances working at Nokia. I talked to HR and she told me I need to stand up for myself more and be stronger lol. Trust me, I did. 
Anyway I transferred departments to IOT and I absolutely loved my new team!!

job_title: Graduate Engineering Trainee GET in Bangalore
pros:
Nokia is a very good place to work.

They always plan things ahead of time like effort estimation, hours needed to complete certain feature.

If someone is stuck somewhere in his/her task then the colleagues help them. 

Don't know about others but atleast my team conducts an evening sync just to solve any blockers the team members might be facing. 

The people and companies policies are respectful. No use of any kind of harsh language. 

In times of wfh, I found my department to be lineant enough to allow stepping away from work for 1-2 hours.
cons:
Nokia has introduced a hybrid/remote working model in 2022. But the catch is employee has to reside in the same state as job location.
If someone really need to work fully remotely then they have to discuss it with 2nd line manager and if there is a business need then only people will be allowed to work fully remotely.

For freshers with 0 years of experience. They have this graduate engineer trainee post the work is good but the compensation is not.

review_title: Good place to work and grow
pros: Interesting projects related to state-of-the-art mobile telecommunication technologies (SW development on different protocol layers), many learning possibilities and carrier paths, small development teams, nice office space (if you prefer to work from office), flexible work scheme or fully remote possible (you can pick what suits you best), business trips from time to time, great atmosphere at work, inclusive and supportive work environment, social benefits and private medical care.
cons: Some technically demanding projects are run in a high pace with tight deadlines. Competences are distributed among teams around the world, so sometime it is challenging to gather required knowledge and know-how to start working on your tasks (e.g. when migrating to the new project). Many time your work with low level HW-SW interfaces, so you really need to know how the HW is designed and how it works - this often implies quite intensive study of HW specs. Some SW tools and CI/CD environment are not always reliable or comfortable in use.

job_title: Technical Support Engineer in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros:
Big company, with unique products that there are no concurrent player with similar.
Good colleagues. Really nice people.
Our boss(line manager) are 24/7 available to help and guide.
cons:
Terrible communication, I know the word is strong but it's true. Every thing goes by broadcast emails in a way that when we start at the morning, we do realize that there are 50 new emails that are not meant for us.

You don't have space to create something new to help the company, I've already tried it.

Many time wasting processes that could be done by a software are, STILL, done by us, in Excel spreadsheets. I mean, processes that take months, part of this is due to the terrible communication between anybody.

The worst part is that your IT competences(AWS, Azure, C++, C#, Python, SQL, etc) except Linux is gonna be wasted. This is NOT to the company to blame but by the role itself.

cons: I began to work in Nokia on March of 2021, all goes well at the beginning. My background was far from telecom sector , but my manager said that I would have the notify period that was needed...In the interview he said about software development in c/c++ , after 3,5 months that was not-existent....ok there was some guidance from the called "buddy" but for all other issues except from writing code ... Naturally, I expressed questions for non-compliance with what has been agreed...What was the result?My manager said me that if u don't like this please resign....I suggested to move me to another department more closely into my background...even if I had done all the asked projects he asked me  the pressure had became extremely annoying... Finally my manager tried to make me to resign, he wrote a fake report for the HR department, it referred that my "buddy" was my Scrum master(he had hired in the Team after me.....) and other lies.... Finally I leave the company in the end of the month... It's a pity for such a giant company to have so bad motivation and behaviour to young people......In my opinion if someone thinks of going on this department please take into consideration all the above and think it again.....Please ask the Informatics trade union of Nokia to take information....they helped me enough.....

- Promised benefits are nearly impossible to get approved, and then usually come in less than promised

Lack of career progression opportunities
- Company does not punish failure or reward success. Some people work 24/7 and still have to fight for recognition.
- Many people are lifers who've been with the company for 20 years in the same role and expect the same for everyone else
- Raises with promotions or increased responsibilities are few and very small if at all

Culture going in the wrong direction
- People are becoming more impersonal and disconnected with remote work
- Decisions that appear detrimental are made without explanation
- Poor work life balance. As the company continues to lay off people more work is thrown onto the people that remain.
- Upper management is very political. They do not answer questions directly or provide any clear direction.

review_title: One of the best companies to work
pros: Nokia is one of the best companies to work into. It has many projects and business units, so if you have the required skill sets you can definitely work in the respective projects you wish to. There is enormous chance to grow personally as well as professionally.
cons: I didn't get the Job location I was told at the time of interview and even the work timings were also quite odd which I was totally unaware before joining. On the very first day of Joining I was at office for almost 12-13 hours and even worse, next day I was told to reach office at 5am in the morning as I had to attend the meeting with the foreign client. I was not given a time to get settled in the new office environment. This schedule was there for whole week and on weekend I had to fly out of India for Onsite assignment. I travelled for almost 18-20 hours and as soon as I landed the foreign land I was told to travel client location. That was quite a sore experience for me.
